required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Sleep Intervention on Social-emotional Development in Early Childhood
clinical_study.official_title: Infant Behavioral Sleep Intervention: Comparative Efficacy Across Assessing Social-emotional Development in Early Childhood

lead_sponsor.agency: Shanghai Jiao Tong University School of Medicine

clinical_study.source: Shanghai Jiao Tong University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: Mental health problems affect 10-20% of children and adolescents worldwide and account for a large portion of global burden of diseases. A growing body of literature suggests that sleep disturbances (e.g., insomnia, sleep deprivation) may result in emotional distress, which in turn may precipitate mood disorders. Recent neuroimaging and neurophysiological findings converge to suggest that emotional networks are activated during sleep. In addition, emotional activation during sleep may be a necessary factor for emotional maturation, and the emergence and maintenance of consciousness in the developing brain. Recent studies support the role of sleep in emotional maturity. Since as early as the 13th week of gestation and neonatal period, smiles and other expressions are extremely common, especially during active REM sleep. Also, it was shown that sleep-state transitions characterized by shifts between quiet sleep and wakefulness are important for an optimal emotional and cognitive development. But studies in early childhood are really scarce compared with those in adults and it makes difficult to draw the conclusion that early sleep intervention would positively affect emotional well-being, and conversely, certain emotions may lead to compromised sleep. Thus, the investigators employ infant sleep intervention protocol to explore the causal relationship of sleep and early sleep-emotional development. The study will provide a better understanding of the multifaceted role of sleep in emotional functions and further demonstrate key component of sleep in mental health and well-being in infants.

detailed_description.textblock:
Study Design: Randomized controlled trial (RCT). Approximately 400 participants will be randomized to a control condition or behavioral sleep intervention condition.
Participants: Participants are healthy infants between the ages of 0 and 12 months and their parents. Parents must be willing to engage in infant behavioral sleep intervention.
Study Procedure: Participants recruitment strategy is direct referrals from Renji hospital, affiliated shanghai jiaotong university school of medicine. Participants will be screened and consented via interview. Individuals (parents) of the interventional group were subject to standardized sleep hygiene education at 5 timepoints when the baby was born, 42 days, 3month, 6month and 9month. Children diagnosed with behavioral insomnia (international diagnostic criteria for sleep disorders II) at 3month, 6month or 9month, investigators should carry out standardized behavioral sleep intervention. For children with sleep disorders in the control group, treatment was in accordance with the current clinical therapy and should be recorded.
Intervention: The intervention consists of 5 times sleep hygiene education and infant standard behavioral sleep protocol. Interventionist will collaborate with the family to design a tailored sleep schedule and bedtime routine. The interventionist will then teach the family a behavioral approach, which involves placing the infant in his/her crib awake.The behavioral approach will be individually tailored for each family (e.g., periodic checks). Parents are educated to implement the behavioral protocol at bedtime and subsequent night wakings.
Measures: Infant sleep will be assessed by parent-report (sleep diary and validated scale) and actiwatch; Functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) Study and eye-tracking, Parent sleep condition, Parent mood condition.
Collaborators on this study include: Renji hospital, affiliated shanghai jiaotong university school of medicine

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: infants are randomly assigned to one of two groups: control or Behavioral Sleep Intervention (intervention).
study_design_info.masking_description: The individuals assessing the Outcomes are blinded to the participant's condition

primary_outcome.time_frame: changes from 3 month, 6 month,9 month and 12 months follow-up
primary_outcome.description: Different sleep parameters, such as sleep onset latency (SOL) and wake after sleep onset (WASO) will be determined using wrist actigraphy. Participants will be provided with an actiwatch after 3 month, 6 month,9 month and 12 months follow-up of the study. The actiwatch will be worn on the non-dominant arm 24 hours a day, except for while bathing, during the 1-week screening period.

primary_outcome.measure: Sleep disorders measured by Brief Infant Sleep Questionnaire
primary_outcome.time_frame: changes from 3 month, 6 month,9 month and 12 months follow-up
primary_outcome.description: Infant sleep problems reported by the mother and according to Brief Infant Sleep Questionnaire (BISQ). It is not a scale. The variables of the questionnaire included 1) nocturnal sleep duration (between the hours of 7 pm and 7 am); 2) daytime sleep duration (between the hours of 7 am and 7 pm); 3) number of night wakenings; 4) duration of wakefulness during the night hours (10 pm to 6 am); 5) nocturnal sleep-onset time (the time when the child falls asleep for the night); 6) settling time (latency to falling asleep for the night); 7) method of falling asleep; 8) location of sleep; 9) preferred body position; 10) age of child; 11) gender of child; 12) birth order; and 13) role of the responder who completed the BISQ. If the child woke up more than 3 times per night, spent more than 1 hour in wakefulness during the night, or spent less than 9 hours in sleep (day and night), then they were considered as poor sleepers

primary_outcome.time_frame: changes from 3 month, 6 month,9 month and 12 months follow-up
primary_outcome.description: The investigators examine the influence of sleep disorders on face processing and neural response at 3 month, 6 month,9 month and 12 months follow-up using synchronized eye-tracking and functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) to uncover the neural mechanism for that sleep disturbance influences social-emotional development.

arm_group.description: Infant sleep monitoring(actiwatch and sleep dairy) and parental surveys

For intervention group, 5 times sleep hygiene education will be introduced to parents and behavioral approach will be given for infants with behavioral insomnia. Parents are instructed to sleep protocols, including a standardized sleep schedule and bedtime routine, as well as other support from a sleep interventionist. Behavioral procedures such as unmodified extinction; graduated extinction (ignoring the infant cries with minimal checks), or camping out

intervention.description: The intervention consists of an infant behavioral sleep protocol. In the standard intervention approach, parents are asked to implement the behavioral protocol at bedtime and at subsequent night wakings and so on

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- The family must have in-home private wireless access that they are willing to share with the study team
- single birth
- Families lives in shanghai for at least 2 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant woman has signs of preterm birth;
- Pregnant woman was diagnosed with gestational diseases, such as pregnancy hypertension, diabetes, etc.; and were diagnosed with chronic diseases such as heart, liver or kidney disease, etc.

facility.name: Shanghai children's medicial center affiliated shanghai jiaotong University School of Medicine
